festivals.name: Dashain
festivals.tagline: Nepal's greatest festival celebrating the eternal victory of good over evil
festivals.description: Dashain is the longest and most auspicious Hindu festival in Nepal, lasting for 15 days from Ashwin Shukla Pratipada to Purnima. It celebrates the victory of goddess Durga over the buffalo demon Mahishasura after a fierce nine-day battle, symbolizing the eternal triumph of dharma over adharma. The festival marks the sacred return home—scattered families reunite, homes are painted anew, and elders bestow blessings through the placing of tika and jamara upon the foreheads of the young. From the planting of barley seeds on Ghatasthapana to the final gathering of Dashami when the sky thunders with kite strings, Dashain weaves together mythology, harvest thanksgiving, and the unbreakable bonds of family.

mythology.summary: Dashain celebrates the nine-night battle where Goddess Durga defeated the shape-shifting buffalo demon Mahishasura, who had terrorized the three worlds after receiving a boon that no god or man could kill him. The gods pooled their divine weapons and energies to create Durga, the one being capable of ending his reign of terror.
mythology.origin_story:
In an age before ages, the asura Mahishasura performed such extreme tapasya that Lord Brahma appeared before him. Cunning in his wish, Mahishasura asked for immortality, but Brahma refused. Instead, Mahishasura requested that no god, demon, or man could kill him—overlooking the power of woman. With this boon, he conquered the three worlds, driving even Indra from his throne.

The desperate gods gathered at Mount Kailash. From their collective fury emerged a blinding radiance. Each god contributed their essence: Shiva gave his trident, Vishnu his chakra, Indra his thunderbolt, Yama his staff of death. From this divine confluence arose Durga—beautiful as the dawn, terrible as the storm—mounted upon a lion.

For nine nights, goddess and demon clashed across heaven and earth. Mahishasura was a master of maya, shifting from buffalo to lion to elephant to warrior. But Durga was patient and relentless. On the tenth day, as Mahishasura charged in his true buffalo form, she pierced his heart with her trident and severed his head with her sword.

Vijaya Dashami—the Tenth Day of Victory—commemorates this momentous triumph. In Nepal, this eternal story takes on local flavor: the goddess is worshipped as Bhagwati in her many temple forms throughout the Kathmandu Valley, and the royal tradition of receiving tika from the Kumari echoes the divine feminine power that saved creation.
legends: The nine forms of Durga (Navadurga) are worshipped across nine nights, each representing a different aspect of the goddess's power.
In Nepal, the Taleju Bhawani temple opens only once a year during Dashain, when thousands queue to receive the goddess's blessing.
The tradition of flying kites during Dashain is said to send messages to the departed ancestors and to invite Indra to stop the monsoon rains.
mythology.historical_context: The Malla and Shah kings institutionalized Dashain as the kingdom's greatest festival. King Prithvi Narayan Shah used the Dashain period for military campaigns, believing the goddess's victory promised success. The tradition of soldiers and officers receiving tika from the king continued until 2008, symbolizing divine sanction for the state.

regional_variations.Kathmandu Valley: Worship of the Taleju temple and Nava Durga traditions
regional_variations.Gorkha: Ancestral home of the Shah dynasty, with royal-style celebrations
regional_variations.Terai: Influenced by North Indian Durga Puja traditions with pandal decorations

daily_rituals.name: Ghatasthapana
daily_rituals.description: The festival begins with planting barley seeds in a sacred vessel (kalash) filled with holy water. A priest determines the auspicious moment based on astrological calculations. The barley will grow into yellow jamara sprouts that are placed on heads during tika on Dashami.

rituals.name: Ghata Sthapana
rituals.description: Setting up the sacred kalash with jamara seeds, cow dung, and holy water in the puja room. The vessel is covered with blessed sand and topped with banana leaves and coconut.

rituals.name: Navaratri Begins
rituals.description: Beginning of the nine nights of Durga worship. Many observe fasts and abstain from meat and alcohol.

daily_rituals.name: Phulpati
daily_rituals.description: The sacred flowers and leaves (phulpati) are brought in a ceremonial procession. Historically, the royal phulpati was carried from Gorkha to Kathmandu with military honors—a 50-mile journey that symbolized the nation's unity under the goddess's blessing.

rituals.name: Phulpati Arrival
rituals.description: Procession of nine types of sacred leaves and flowers arrives at the Dashain Ghar. Includes leaves of the bilva, pomegranate, mango, ashoka, bel, banana, and other sacred plants.

rituals.name: Temple Visits
rituals.description: Devotees visit Bhagwati temples across the valley to offer flowers and receive blessings.

daily_rituals.name: Maha Ashtami
daily_rituals.description: The Eighth Night marks the peak of Durga's battle. Hundreds of temples conduct animal sacrifices and special pujas. The night is especially auspicious, with devotees staying awake for worship.

rituals.name: Astami Puja
rituals.description: Special offerings to Durga with red hibiscus flowers, vermillion, and dedication of weapons.

rituals.name: Kaal Ratri
rituals.description: The 'Dark Night' when Durga takes her most fierce form as Kali to deliver the final blow to evil. Temples remain open all night.

rituals.name: Animal Sacrifice
rituals.description: Blood offerings of buffaloes, goats, and chickens at temples and government offices. Each sacrifice symbolizes the killing of Mahishasura.

daily_rituals.name: Maha Navami
daily_rituals.description: The Ninth Day commemorates Durga's final victory. Vehicles, tools, and weapons receive blessings. The Kot (armory) ceremonies honor the state's instruments of protection.

rituals.name: Navami Puja
rituals.description: Final day of the nine-night worship. The goddess is offered blood sacrifice as thanksgiving for victory.

rituals.name: Vehicle and Weapon Blessing
rituals.description: Cars, motorcycles, buses, tractors, and all vehicles are decorated with marigolds and blessed. Tools and weapons are worshipped.

rituals.name: Vishwakarma Puja
rituals.description: Craftsmen and factory workers worship their tools and machinery.

daily_rituals.name: Vijaya Dashami
daily_rituals.description: The Day of Victory! Families gather as elders place tika (vermillion, rice, and yogurt) on foreheads and jamara (barley sprouts) on heads of younger family members, bestowing blessings for the coming year. It is the most important day of the Nepali calendar.

rituals.name: Tika and Jamara
rituals.description: Elders prepare the sacred tika mixture and place it on the foreheads of younger family members while reciting mantras of blessing. Yellow jamara sprouts are placed on the head. Gifts of money (dakshina) are given.

rituals.name: Visiting Elders
rituals.description: Younger family members travel to receive tika from all elder relatives—grandparents, uncles, aunts. The procession continues for up to five days.

rituals.name: Kite Flying
rituals.description: The skies fill with kites of all colors. Tradition says the kites invite departed ancestors to receive offerings and signal Indra to stop the rains.

daily_rituals.name: Kojagrat Purnima
daily_rituals.description: The full moon marks the final day of Dashain. Laxmi puja is performed, and those who stayed awake are said to receive the goddess's blessing of prosperity.

rituals.name: Laxmi Puja
rituals.description: Worship of the goddess of wealth on the full moon night.

rituals.name: Final Tika
rituals.description: Last day to receive tika from elders for those who couldn't visit earlier.

festivals.name: Tihar
festivals.tagline: Festival of lights honoring the sacred bond between humans, animals, and the divine
festivals.description: Tihar is Nepal's Festival of Lights, a five-day celebration that moves from honoring the animal kingdom—crows who are messengers of Yama, dogs who guard the gates of the afterlife, and cows who provide sustenance—to worshipping Laxmi the goddess of prosperity, and finally to Bhai Tika, the most tender Nepali tradition where sisters bless their brothers with elaborate tikkas and prayers for long life. Unlike any other festival, Tihar traverses the boundary between life and death, petitioning Yama the death-god for the lives of beloved brothers, filling the darkness with thousands of oil lamps, and celebrating the Newari New Year.

mythology.summary: Tihar honors the legend of Yamuna, who saved her brother Yama (the god of death) from dying, establishing the sacred bond of Bhai Tika. The festival also celebrates Laxmi, who wanders the earth on Kartik Amavasya seeking well-lit homes to bless with prosperity.
mythology.origin_story:
Long ago, the gods realized that even Yama—lord of death himself—was destined to die. His devoted sister Yamuna refused to accept this fate. When Yama came to claim his own life on a foretold day, Yamuna wept and applied a sacred tika on his forehead, circling him with a garland of amaranth flowers.

Moved by her devotion, Yama granted her a boon: he would live as long as the tika remained on his forehead. And so she applied seven colors of tika, and he lived. In return, Yama blessed all sisters who perform this ritual—that brothers who receive tika from their sisters would be protected from untimely death for one full year.

From that day, Bhai Tika became the most sacred bond in Nepali culture. Sisters pray for their brothers' long lives, and brothers pledge to protect their sisters. The walnuts placed in the puja represent longevity; the sel roti, the cycle of life; and the seven-colored tika, the rainbow of protection against all manner of misfortune.

The other days of Tihar honor the attendants of Yama: the crow who brings news of death, the dog who guards the gates of Yamalok, and the cow whose back provides the bridge across the river of death. By honoring these creatures, we petition for safe passage in the afterlife.
legends: Laxmi favors homes that are clean and well-lit; a darkened house on her night means a year of poverty.
The deusi-bhailo groups who sing door-to-door are said to bring blessings from Laxmi herself.
Dogs are especially cherished on Kukur Tihar because they helped Bhairava guard Pashupatinath.
mythology.historical_context: While Diwali is celebrated across South Asia, Nepal's Tihar has unique elements: the animal worship days are distinctly Nepali, and Mha Puja (self-worship) on Kartik Shukla Pratipada is exclusively Newari—marking Nepal Sambat New Year. The tradition of deusi-bhailo (caroling groups) is also unique to Nepal.

daily_rituals.name: Kaag Tihar
daily_rituals.description: Crows are worshipped as the messengers of Yama, the god of death. Families offer food to crows early in the morning, petitioning for no sad news in the coming year.

rituals.name: Crow Offering
rituals.description: Rice, sweets, and sel roti are placed on banana leaves or brass plates on rooftops and open areas for crows. Families call out 'Kaa-kaa' to attract the birds.

daily_rituals.name: Kukur Tihar
daily_rituals.description: Dogs are honored as the guardians of Yama's realm and loyal companions. Dogs—pets and strays alike—are adorned with marigold garlands and red tika, and fed with special treats.

rituals.name: Dog Puja
rituals.description: Dogs receive tika on their foreheads, marigold garlands around their necks, and are fed meat, sel roti, and treats. Even stray dogs on streets are honored.

daily_rituals.name: Gai Tihar & Laxmi Puja
daily_rituals.description: The third day honors the cow as sacred mother and, in the evening, welcomes Laxmi, goddess of wealth. Homes are cleaned spotless, and the night glitters with countless oil lamps.

rituals.name: Cow Worship
rituals.description: Cows are garlanded with marigolds and fed special food. Their horns may be painted, and they are worshipped as Laxmi herself in bovine form.

rituals.name: Deep Cleaning
rituals.description: Homes are thoroughly cleaned and decorated. Rangoli designs are created near doorways using colored powders and flower petals.

rituals.name: Laxmi Puja
rituals.description: As darkness falls, thousands of diyo (oil lamps) are lit inside and outside homes. Goddess Laxmi is invoked with mantras. Account books may be placed before her image for blessing.

rituals.name: Bhailo Groups
rituals.description: Groups of women and girls go door-to-door singing bhailo songs, receiving money and treats. The songs invoke Laxmi's blessings on the household.

daily_rituals.name: Govardhan Puja & Mha Puja
daily_rituals.description: Oxen are worshipped for their labor. In the Newar community, this is the most important day: Mha Puja (self-worship) marks Nepal Sambat New Year, and the day celebrates one's own body and soul.

rituals.name: Ox Worship
rituals.description: Oxen and bulls are garlanded and fed special food in recognition of their work in the fields.

rituals.name: Mha Puja (Newari)
rituals.description: Family members sit in a circle on intricate mandalas. Each person's body is ritually purified and worshipped—a unique tradition of honoring one's own existence.

rituals.name: Deusi Groups
rituals.description: Groups of men and boys go door-to-door singing deusi songs, playfully demanding donations and blessing the household.

daily_rituals.name: Bhai Tika
daily_rituals.description: The most emotionally significant day of Tihar. Sisters apply seven-colored tika on brothers' foreheads and garland them with marigolds, praying for their long life. Brothers give gifts and pledge protection.

rituals.name: Bathing and Fasting
rituals.description: Sisters wake early, bathe, and may fast until the ritual is complete.

rituals.name: Oil Circle (Tel ko Gola)
rituals.description: Sisters pour mustard oil in a circle around their brother, warding off Yama from approaching him for the coming year.

rituals.name: Tika and Garland
rituals.description: The seven-colored tika (saptarangi tika) is applied on the brother's forehead. A garland of globe amaranth (makhamali) is placed around his neck. Sisters wave a tray with diya, flowers, and food offerings.

rituals.name: Special Foods
rituals.description: Brothers eat sel roti (ring-shaped fried bread), khuwa sweets, and walnuts. The walnut is cracked with the teeth—a test of strength and symbol of longevity.

rituals.name: Gifts and Pledges
rituals.description: Brothers give gifts (money, clothes, or jewelry) to their sisters and pledge to protect and support them.

festivals.name: Holi
festivals.tagline: Festival of colors celebrating spring and love
festivals.description: Holi is the festival of colors, celebrated on the full moon of Falgun. People throw colored powder (abir) and water at each other, dancing and celebrating the arrival of spring. The day before, Holika Dahan marks the burning of the demoness Holika, symbolizing victory over evil. In the Terai, Holi is celebrated with great enthusiasm, while in the hills it follows a day later.

festivals.name: Indra Jatra
festivals.tagline: Kathmandu's grandest street festival with the Living Goddess
festivals.summary: Indra Jatra is Kathmandu's most spectacular street festival, honoring the god Indra and featuring the Living Goddess Kumari in a chariot procession through the ancient streets. The eight-day celebration marks the end of monsoon and the beginning of autumn with masked dances, classical music, and ancient rituals dating back to the Malla era.
festivals.description: Indra Jatra is Kathmandu's most spectacular street festival, lasting eight days in September. It honors the god Indra and features the appearance of Kumari, the Living Goddess, who is carried through the streets in a chariot. The Lakhey demon dance, masked dances of Pulukishi (elephant), and classical Newari music fill the old city. The festival marks the end of monsoon and the beginning of the autumn festival season. It culminates with the chariot procession through Kathmandu Durbar Square.

mythology.summary: Indra Jatra celebrates the ancient story of Indra, King of Heaven, who descended to earth to gather parijat flowers for his mother Dagini. Captured by vigilant Kathmandu farmers who mistook him for a thief, he was bound and displayed publicly. When Dagini revealed her son's divine identity, the people were ashamed. As atonement, Dagini made a covenant: an eight-day festival honoring Indra, in exchange for morning dew for crops and safe passage for departed souls to heaven. This covenant established Indra Jatra, binding mortals and gods in eternal celebration.
mythology.origin_story:
In the ancient times when the boundary between heaven and earth was thinner than a spider's silk, there lived in the celestial realm of Swargaloka the great King of the Gods—Indra, Lord of Thunder, Bearer of the Vajra, and Master of the Monsoons. His palace, Amaravati, gleamed with a thousand jewels, and his elephant Airavata bore him across the clouds that brought life-giving rain to the mortal world below.

Indra's mother, the goddess Dagini, was known throughout the heavens for her devotion to sacred rituals. Each year, she performed elaborate pujas that required the most precious offerings, and chief among these was the parijat flower—a celestial blossom of extraordinary beauty that grew only in specific groves scattered between the realms.

One autumn, as the monsoon season drew to a close over the Kathmandu Valley, Dagini summoned her son. The parijat flowers she needed for her upcoming ritual could only be found in a secret garden that had manifested in the mortal realm, hidden among the rice paddies and temples of Nepala. Indra, ever the dutiful son, disguised himself as a common traveler and descended to Earth under cover of night.

The Kathmandu Valley in those days was ruled by the Licchavi kings, and the people were known for their fierce independence and deep suspicion of strangers. Indra wandered through the sleeping city, past the great stupas and into the fields where the parijat trees bloomed silver in the moonlight. He began gathering the flowers, filling his celestial pouch with their intoxicating fragrance.

But the farmers of Kathmandu were vigilant. A group of villagers, returning late from a wedding celebration, spotted the mysterious figure among the flowers. They did not recognize the King of Heaven—for how could they? Indra appeared as nothing more than a common thief stealing their precious blooms. With ropes woven from rice straw, they bound the god's hands and dragged him to the center of the city.

Morning came, and the captured 'thief' was displayed at the crossroads near what is now Maru Tole. The people gathered, laughing and jeering. Children threw old vegetables. Market women clucked their tongues. The great Indra, humiliated beyond measure, could not reveal his true identity—for to use his divine powers against mortals would violate the cosmic law that even gods must obey.

Days passed. In the heavens, Dagini grew worried. Her son had not returned, and the ritual date approached. She descended to earth on a moonless night, her form cloaked in mist. Following the thread of divine energy that connected her to her child, she arrived at the crossroads to find Indra still bound, his godly radiance dimmed by mortal ropes.

Dagini's revelation shook the valley like an earthquake. She unveiled her true form—resplendent, terrifying, beautiful—and the mortals fell to their knees. 'You have bound the Lord of Rain,' she declared, her voice echoing from the mountains. 'The one who brings the monsoon, who fills your rivers and grows your rice. What offering can you make to atone for this insult?'

The people wept with fear and shame. The elders gathered and begged forgiveness. They promised festivals, sacrifices, eternal devotion. They offered to build temples in Indra's name.

Dagini considered their pleas. She looked at her son, still patient despite his ordeal. And in that moment, she made a covenant that would bind heaven and earth for all time: 'Each year, when the monsoon ends and the harvest begins, you shall honor my son with eight days of celebration. You shall erect a great pole in his name, and your goddess Kumari shall emerge to bless your people. In return, I shall send the morning dew to nurture your winter crops, and I shall personally guide the souls of your departed loved ones to the realm of the ancestors.'

The people agreed with joy and relief. Indra was released, and as he ascended back to heaven, he blessed the valley with abundant harvests for generations to come. The farmers who had captured him became the hereditary guardians of the Indra Dhwaja, the sacred pole that is raised each year to commemorate his visit.

And so began Indra Jatra, the greatest street festival of Kathmandu. For over a thousand years, the people have remembered this divine encounter. The Lakhey demon dances through the streets as a reminder of the masked spirits that once roamed freely. The Pulukishi elephant symbolizes Airavata searching for his master. And when the Kumari emerges in her golden chariot, she carries forward the blessing that Dagini promised—prosperity for the living and peace for the dead.

To this day, on the fifth day of the festival called Upaku Wanegu, families light oil lamps along the routes their deceased relatives once walked, creating paths of fire to guide their souls to heaven. It is said that on this night, the veil between worlds grows thin once more, and Dagini herself descends to fulfill her ancient promise, gathering the spirits of the departed and leading them to eternal rest.

This is why Indra Jatra is not merely a festival—it is a covenant renewed, a bond between mortals and gods, between the living and the dead, between the earth that sustains us and the heavens that watch over us. Eight days each year, Kathmandu becomes the crossroads of all realms, and in the faces of the dancing Lakhey and the serene Kumari, we glimpse the eternal truth: that even gods walk among us, and even the mightiest can be humbled by the people they serve.

key_deities.name: Indra
key_deities.role: Central deity, King of Heaven and god of rain, honored for bringing monsoon
key_deities.significance: The festival celebrates Indra's capture and release, thanking him for rainfall

key_deities.name: Dagini
key_deities.role: Indra's mother who descends to free her son
key_deities.significance: Represents maternal love and the promise of dew for crops

key_deities.name: Kumari
key_deities.significance: Gives tika blessing to ensure prosperity; her emergence marks festival climax

key_deities.name: Bhairav
key_deities.role: Fierce form of Shiva, protector deity of Kathmandu
key_deities.significance: The Akash Bhairav and Kal Bhairav images are revealed during the festival

mythology.cultural_significance: Indra Jatra represents the unique synthesis of Hindu, Buddhist, and indigenous Newari traditions. It demonstrates how the Kathmandu Valley transformed an imported Hindu deity into a local celebration intertwined with ancestor worship and royal authority. The Kumari procession legitimized Malla and later Shah rule, as the king would receive tika from the Living Goddess.
mythology.symbolic_meaning: The festival symbolizes the cycle of monsoon and harvest, the relationship between gods and humans, the reverence for ancestors, and the continuity of divine feminine power through the Kumari tradition.

days.name: Yosin Thane
days.description: The Indra Dhwaja (pole) is erected at Basantapur in Kathmandu Durbar Square. This 50-foot wooden pole wrapped in cloth symbolizes the lingam of Indra and marks the beginning of the festival. Families begin preparing for ancestor worship.

days.name: Bhairav Pratishtha
days.description: The giant mask of Akash Bhairav is unveiled at Indra Chowk. The fearsome deity's face is displayed for public worship. Throughout the day, devotees offer flowers and sacrifices.

days.name: Lakhey Day
days.description: The Lakhey (demon dancer) emerges from Lakhey Tole and dances through the streets. This fierce masked figure with bulging eyes and red furry costume is believed to protect children from evil spirits. Multiple Lakhey performers dance in different neighborhoods.

days.name: Pulukishi
days.description: The Pulukishi (elephant) dance is performed. Two men inside a white elephant costume dance through the streets, representing Indra's elephant mount Airavata who came searching for his master.

days.name: Upaku Wanegu
days.description: Families light oil lamps along streets passed by deceased relatives, creating a path for their souls. This day honors the dead and connects to Dagini's promise to take souls to heaven. The city glows with thousands of lights after dark.

days.name: Yenya Punhi (Main Day)
days.description: The climax of Indra Jatra. The Kumari emerges from Kumari Ghar in her elaborate chariot, accompanied by chariots bearing Ganesh and Bhairav. She is pulled through the streets by devotees while giving blessings. Rice beer (aila) flows from the mouth of the Kal Bhairav statue.

days.name: Second Chariot Day
days.description: The Kumari's chariot continues its circuit through old Kathmandu, visiting different neighborhoods. Masked dances continue throughout the day. The atmosphere is festive with music and celebration.

days.name: Yenya Kwachaley (Pole Lowering)
days.description: The Indra Dhwaja pole is ceremonially lowered at Basantapur, marking the end of the festival. The Kumari returns to Kumari Ghar. The masks of Bhairav are covered until next year. Indra Jatra ends, and preparations for Dashain begin.

festivals.name: Teej
festivals.tagline: Women's festival of fasting, dancing, and devotion
festivals.description: Teej is a three-day festival primarily celebrated by Hindu women. They dress in red saris, sing traditional songs, and fast for the well-being of their husbands and families. The festival honors goddess Parvati and her devotion to Lord Shiva. Women gather at temples, especially Pashupatinath, to perform rituals and offer prayers. The day before Teej, called Dar Khane Din, women feast before beginning their fast.

festivals.name: Maha Shivaratri
festivals.tagline: Night of Lord Shiva with all-night vigils at Pashupatinath
festivals.description: Maha Shivaratri is one of the most important Hindu festivals, celebrated on the 14th day of the dark fortnight in Falgun. Devotees fast and stay awake all night in honor of Lord Shiva. Pashupatinath Temple becomes the center of celebrations, attracting thousands of sadhus (holy men) from across South Asia who gather to smoke chillums, perform rituals, and meditate. The temple resonates with chants of 'Om Namah Shivaya' throughout the night.

festivals.name: Buddha Jayanti
festivals.tagline: Celebrating Buddha's birth, enlightenment, and passing
festivals.description: Buddha Jayanti marks the birth, enlightenment, and death of Gautama Buddha, all believed to have occurred on the same day. In Nepal, it's celebrated on the full moon of Baisakh with processions, prayers, and visits to Buddhist sites. Lumbini, Buddha's birthplace, and Swayambhunath and Boudhanath in Kathmandu see the largest gatherings. Devotees circumambulate stupas, light butter lamps, and offer prayers.

festivals.name: Janai Purnima
festivals.tagline: Sacred thread ceremony and Raksha Bandhan
festivals.description: Janai Purnima is the full moon day when Hindu men change their sacred thread (janai) in a ceremony of purification and renewal. Everyone receives a sacred thread (raksha) tied on their wrist for protection throughout the coming year. It's also celebrated as Raksha Bandhan in some communities, where sisters tie threads on their brothers' wrists. Gosaikunda Lake sees thousands of pilgrims who trek there for a sacred dip.
festivals.who_celebrates: Hindus, especially Bahun and Chhetri communities

festivals.name: Gai Jatra
festivals.tagline: Festival of cows honoring the deceased with humor and satire
festivals.description: Gai Jatra is a unique Newari festival where families who lost members in the past year lead cows (or boys dressed as cows) through the streets, believing cows help guide souls to heaven. Started by King Pratap Malla to comfort his queen after their son's death, it evolved into a carnival of satire and comedy, with people mocking politicians, social issues, and celebrities. Newspapers publish satirical editions, and the streets fill with colorful processions.

festivals.name: Mha Puja
festivals.tagline: Worship of self and Nepal Sambat New Year
festivals.description: Mha Puja falls on the fourth day of Tihar and is unique to the Newari community. It marks Nepal Sambat New Year and involves worshipping oneself, acknowledging one's life force and divine essence. Elaborate mandalas are created on the floor, and each family member sits in their designated spot for the ritual. The ceremony celebrates the divine within each person, promoting self-respect and spiritual awareness.

festivals.name: Yomari Punhi
festivals.tagline: Newari harvest festival with sweet rice dumplings
festivals.description: Yomari Punhi is a Newari festival celebrating the rice harvest. Families make yomari, crescent-shaped rice flour dumplings filled with chaku (sweet molasses) or khuwa (dried milk). The distinctive fish or fig-shaped dumplings are steamed and offered to Annapurna, the goddess of grains. Children go door-to-door singing for yomari. It's celebrated on the full moon of Poush (December) and is associated with joy and plenty.

festivals.name: Maghe Sankranti
festivals.tagline: Winter solstice celebration with special foods and holy baths
festivals.description: Maghe Sankranti marks the transition of the sun into Capricorn and the first day of the month of Magh. It's celebrated with special foods including til ko laddu (sesame sweets), yam, ghee, and chaku. People take holy dips in rivers, especially at Devghat where the Trisuli and Kali Gandaki rivers meet. The Tharu community celebrates it as Maghi, their New Year, with great cultural festivities.

festivals.name: Nepali New Year
festivals.tagline: Beginning of the Bikram Sambat calendar year
festivals.description: Nepali New Year (Naya Barsha) falls on Baishakh 1 and marks the beginning of the Bikram Sambat calendar. It's celebrated with family gatherings, special foods, and cultural programs. The day is a national holiday, and people visit temples and exchange greetings. In Bhaktapur, the Bisket Jatra chariot festival coincides with New Year celebrations, making it an especially vibrant time in the ancient city.

festivals.name: Bisket Jatra
festivals.tagline: Bhaktapur's dramatic New Year chariot festival
festivals.description: Bisket Jatra is Bhaktapur's spectacular New Year celebration and one of Nepal's most dramatic festivals. Massive chariots carrying images of Bhairab and Bhadrakali are pulled through the narrow streets by competing neighborhoods. A giant lingam pole (Yoshin) is erected in Khalna Tole, and on New Year's Day, the pole is toppled, marking the new year with cheers and celebration. The nine-day festival features traditional music, dances, and feasts.

festivals.name: Ghode Jatra
festivals.tagline: Horse parade festival at Tundikhel
festivals.description: Ghode Jatra is a unique horse parade festival held at Tundikhel in the heart of Kathmandu. According to legend, the thundering hooves keep the evil demon Tundi underground. The Nepal Army performs spectacular horse acrobatics, races, and gymnastics displays. The President attends the ceremony, and it's one of Kathmandu's most popular festivals, drawing large crowds to witness the equestrian displays.

festivals.name: Rato Machhindranath Jatra
festivals.tagline: Nepal's longest chariot festival in Patan
festivals.description: Rato Machhindranath Jatra in Patan is Nepal's longest festival, with the massive chariot procession lasting about a month. The deity Rato Machhindranath is revered by both Hindus (as a form of Avalokiteshvara/Shiva) and Buddhists (as Karunamaya Lokeshwor). The highlight is the Bhoto Jatra, the display of the sacred jeweled vest, traditionally witnessed by the head of state. The 60-foot chariot slowly moves through Patan's ancient streets.

festivals.name: Chhath Parva
festivals.tagline: Ancient sun worship festival at riverbanks
festivals.description: Chhath is an ancient Hindu festival dedicated to the Sun God (Surya) and Chhathi Maiya. Primarily celebrated in the Terai and Madhesh region, devotees fast for 36 hours without water and offer prayers at riverbanks and ponds at sunrise and sunset. Women stand waist-deep in water offering arghya to the rising and setting sun. The four-day festival requires rigorous discipline and purity, believed to bring prosperity and cure ailments.

festivals.name: Lhosar
festivals.tagline: Tibetan New Year celebrations of mountain communities
festivals.description: Lhosar is the New Year celebration of Nepal's Tibetan-speaking communities including Sherpa, Tamang, and Gurung peoples. Each group celebrates on different dates: Sonam Lhosar (Tamang), Gyalpo Lhosar (Sherpa/Tibetan), and Tamu Lhosar (Gurung). Celebrations include traditional dances, feasts, monastary visits, and cultural programs. Boudhanath Stupa becomes a center of celebration for the Tibetan community.

festivals.name: Krishna Janmashtami
festivals.tagline: Birthday celebration of Lord Krishna
festivals.description: Krishna Janmashtami celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu. Devotees fast until midnight when Krishna is believed to have been born, then break their fast with special prasad. The Krishna Mandir in Patan Durbar Square becomes the center of celebration, with thousands queuing to offer prayers. Temples are decorated, and devotees sing bhajans throughout the night.

festivals.name: Ram Navami
festivals.tagline: Birthday of Lord Rama
festivals.description: Ram Navami celebrates the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh avatar of Vishnu and hero of the Ramayana epic. Devotees visit temples, especially in Janakpur (the birthplace of Sita, Rama's consort). The day is marked by readings of the Ramayana, bhajan singing, and special pujas. Janakpur's Ram Janaki Temple sees elaborate celebrations with thousands of pilgrims.

festivals.name: Saraswati Puja
festivals.tagline: Worship of the goddess of knowledge and arts
festivals.description: Saraswati Puja (also called Basant Panchami) honors Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, music, and the arts. Students worship their books and musical instruments, and many children are taught to write their first letters on this auspicious day. Wearing yellow clothes symbolizes the arrival of spring. Saraswati temples see long queues of students seeking blessings for academic success.

festivals.name: Udhauli Parva
festivals.tagline: Kirat migration festival of the Rai and Limbu communities
festivals.description: Udhauli is celebrated by the Kirat (Rai and Limbu) communities marking the migration of birds and people from higher altitudes to lower warmer regions as winter approaches. It's part of the Sakela festival cycle and features the famous Sakela dance (also called Chandi Nach). Dancers mimic movements of birds, animals, and farming activities in a communal celebration of nature and agricultural life.

festivals.name: Ubhauli Parva
festivals.tagline: Kirat spring migration festival with Sakela dance
festivals.description: Ubhauli is the spring counterpart to Udhauli, celebrated by Kirat communities marking migration from lower to higher altitudes as summer approaches. The festival features the energetic Sakela dance performed around a ceremonial altar. Dancers in traditional dress perform movements depicting nature, farming, and hunting. Tundikhel in Kathmandu hosts massive Ubhauli celebrations drawing thousands of Kirat people.

festivals.name: Nag Panchami
festivals.tagline: Worship of the serpent gods for protection
festivals.description: Nag Panchami is dedicated to the worship of Nag (serpent) deities. Pictures of serpents are posted above doorways, and offerings of milk, honey, and rice are made to snake images and live snakes. The Nag Pokhari in Kathmandu and various temples see devotees offering prayers for protection from snakebites and diseases. The festival honors the mythological role of serpents as guardians of water and treasure.

festivals.name: Fagu Purnima
festivals.tagline: The full moon day of Holi celebrations
festivals.description: Fagu Purnima is the full moon day in Falgun that marks the main Holi celebration in the hills. While Terai celebrates Holi a day earlier, the hill communities observe it on this day with color-throwing and water-splashing festivities. Young people roam the streets with colored powder and pichkaris (water guns). The ancient celebration marks the end of winter and the fertility of spring.

festivals.name: Mata Tirtha Aunsi
festivals.tagline: Mother's Day - honoring mothers living and deceased
festivals.description: Mata Tirtha Aunsi (Mother's Day) is celebrated on the new moon of Baisakh. Those with living mothers give gifts and treat them to meals. Those whose mothers have passed visit Mata Tirtha Kunda in Kathmandu to offer prayers and take ritual baths in the sacred pond.

festivals.name: Gokarne Aunsi
festivals.tagline: Father's Day - honoring fathers with Shiva worship
festivals.description: Gokarne Aunsi (Father's Day) is celebrated on the new moon of Bhadra. Those with living fathers give gifts and special meals. Those whose fathers have passed visit Gokarna Mahadev Temple to perform shraddha rituals for the deceased.

festivals.name: Bhoto Jatra
festivals.tagline: Display of the sacred vest at the climax of Rato Machhindranath
festivals.description: Bhoto Jatra marks the climax of the month-long Rato Machhindranath Jatra. A sacred jeweled vest (bhoto) is displayed publicly from the chariot, traditionally in the presence of the head of state. The vest is connected to a legend of a farmer and a nag (serpent) king.

festivals.name: Biswakarma Puja
festivals.tagline: Worship of tools and machinery honoring the divine architect
festivals.description: Biswakarma Puja honors Lord Biswakarma, the divine architect and craftsman. Workers worship their tools, machinery, and vehicles. Factories and workshops are decorated, and pujas are performed for workplace safety and prosperity.

festivals.name: Deepawali
festivals.tagline: Festival of lights on Laxmi Puja day
festivals.description: Deepawali, also known as Laxmi Puja, is the main day of Tihar when homes are decorated with oil lamps (diyo) and rangoli designs to welcome goddess Laxmi, the deity of wealth. Houses are thoroughly cleaned and lit brilliantly to attract the goddess.

festivals.name: Bhai Tika
festivals.tagline: Sisters bless brothers with tika and flower garlands
festivals.description: Bhai Tika is the fifth and final day of Tihar when sisters apply elaborate tika to their brothers' foreheads and give them makhamali (marigold) garlands. Brothers give gifts in return. The ritual celebrates the bond between siblings.

festivals.name: Sithi Nakha
festivals.tagline: Newari festival of cleaning wells and water sources
festivals.description: Sithi Nakha marks the beginning of the monsoon season. On this day, communities clean hitis (stone water spouts), wells, and water sources. It's an environmental festival emphasizing the importance of water conservation. Associated with Kumar (Kartikeya).

festivals.name: Harishayani Ekadashi
festivals.tagline: Day Lord Vishnu goes to cosmic sleep
festivals.description: Harishayani Ekadashi marks the beginning of Chaturmas, the four-month period when Lord Vishnu is believed to sleep. No auspicious activities like weddings are performed until Prabodhini Ekadashi when Vishnu awakens.

festivals.name: Ropain Jatra
festivals.tagline: Rice planting festival with songs and mud celebration
festivals.description: Ropain (Asar 15) celebrates the beginning of rice planting season. Farmers plant rice seedlings while singing traditional songs. It's also celebrated with dahi chiura (yogurt and beaten rice). City dwellers sometimes join in the mud-splashing festivities.

festivals.name: Nag Purnima
festivals.tagline: Full moon serpent worship during Shravan
festivals.description: Nag Purnima is the full moon of Shravan, when devotees offer milk and prayers to serpent deities. Pictures of nagas are placed above doorways as protection. Related to but distinct from Nag Panchami.

festivals.name: Gaura Parva
festivals.tagline: Far-western Nepal's major women's festival
festivals.description: Gaura Parva is the biggest festival of far-western Nepal, primarily for women of the Thakuri, Chhetri, and Brahman communities. Women fast and perform rituals for their husbands' well-being, similar to Teej but with regional traditions.

festivals.name: Deusi Bhailo
festivals.tagline: Traditional door-to-door singing during Tihar
festivals.description: Deusi Bhailo is a tradition during Tihar where groups go door-to-door singing traditional songs. Boys perform Deusi and girls perform Bhailo, receiving money and sweets. The songs praise Laxmi and wish prosperity on households.

festivals.name: Tamu Lhosar
festivals.tagline: Gurung New Year celebration
festivals.description: Tamu Lhosar is the New Year celebration of the Gurung (Tamu) community, typically falling in late December. Marked by traditional dances, feasts, and cultural programs celebrating Gurung heritage and identity.

festivals.name: Sonam Lhosar
festivals.tagline: Tamang New Year celebration
festivals.description: Sonam Lhosar is the New Year of the Tamang community, usually in late January/early February. Celebrations include traditional Tamang selo dance, feasting, and monastery visits. Boudhanath is a major celebration site.

festivals.name: Gyalpo Lhosar
festivals.tagline: Sherpa and Tibetan New Year celebration
festivals.description: Gyalpo Lhosar is celebrated by Sherpa and Tibetan communities, following the Tibetan calendar. Celebrations include monastery visits, traditional dances, and feasts. Major celebrations at Boudhanath stupa.

festivals.name: Maghi
festivals.tagline: Tharu New Year and harvest festival
festivals.description: Maghi is the New Year and most important festival of the Tharu community, coinciding with Maghe Sankranti. Marked by traditional Tharu stick dances, feasting, and remembrance of ancestors. Historically also marks freedom from bonded labor.

festivals.name: Prabodhini Ekadashi
festivals.tagline: Awakening of Lord Vishnu from cosmic sleep
festivals.description: Prabodhini Ekadashi, also called Haribodhini Ekadashi, marks the end of Chaturmas when Vishnu awakens. Wedding season begins after this day. Devotees visit Vishnu temples, especially Budhanilkantha.

festivals.name: Rato Matsyendranath Snan
festivals.tagline: Ritual bathing ceremony of the Red Machhindranath deity
festivals.description: Before the great Rato Machhindranath Jatra begins, the deity undergoes a ritual bathing ceremony. The idol is repainted and prepared for its month-long chariot journey through Patan.

festivals.name: Seto Machhindranath Jatra
festivals.tagline: White Machhindranath chariot procession in Kathmandu
festivals.description: The chariot festival of Seto (White) Machhindranath in Kathmandu, shorter than its Patan counterpart. The chariot is pulled through the streets of old Kathmandu during Indra Jatra.

festivals.name: Yanya Punhi
festivals.tagline: Indra Jatra's Newari name - Kathmandu's grandest celebration
festivals.description: Yanya Punhi is the Newari name for the Indra Jatra festival. It means 'festival of the capital' and represents Kathmandu's biggest annual celebration featuring masked dances, the Living Goddess procession, and Kal Bhairav worship.

festivals.name: Ghatasthapana
festivals.tagline: First day of Dashain - sowing jamara seeds
festivals.description: Ghatasthapana marks the first day of Dashain when a kalash (sacred vessel) is established and barley seeds are sown in sand. These grow into yellow jamara grass used for tika on Vijaya Dashami. The nine nights of Navaratri begin.

festivals.name: Maha Ashtami
festivals.tagline: Eighth day of Dashain - Kali worship and animal sacrifice
festivals.description: Maha Ashtami is the eighth day of Dashain, the most important day for Kali worship and animal sacrifices. The fierce goddess is worshipped at midnight in a ritual called Kal Ratri. Temples like Dakshinkali see heavy crowds.

festivals.name: Maha Navami
festivals.tagline: Ninth day of Dashain - worship of tools and vehicles
festivals.description: Maha Navami is the ninth day of Dashain. All vehicles, tools, and instruments are worshipped. The army performs special pujas at Kot. Taleju Temple opens to the public for the only day of the year.

festivals.name: Vijaya Dashami
festivals.tagline: Main day of Dashain - tika and jamara blessings from elders
festivals.description: Vijaya Dashami is the main day of Dashain when families gather for tika. Elders place rice, yogurt, and vermillion on foreheads and give jamara (barley sprouts) as blessings. The victory of Durga over Mahishasura is celebrated.

festivals.name: Gyalpo Lhosar
festivals.tagline: Sherpa New Year celebrating high mountain culture and traditions
festivals.description: Gyalpo Lhosar is the Sherpa New Year, celebrated in the high Himalayan regions of Nepal, particularly in Solukhumbu, Dolakha, and Sindhupalchok. The festival marks the beginning of the Tibetan lunar calendar and includes monastery prayers, traditional dances, feasting on Sherpa delicacies like khapse (fried bread) and butter tea, and visiting family and friends. Homes are decorated, and the atmosphere is festive with traditional music and ceremonial offerings at Buddhist monasteries.
